fields.article_content_en:
In Python programming, a variable is like a box where you can store information. Think of it as a label that you stick on a value so you can reuse it later in your code without needing to remember exactly what the value was. This makes the code easier to read and modify.

To create a variable in Python, you simply give it a name and assign a value with the equal sign (`=`). Here are some examples:

<code-block>
name = "Jean"
age = 19
average = 85.5
student = True
</code-block>

In these examples, <inline-code>name</inline-code>, <inline-code>age</inline-code>, <inline-code>average</inline-code>, and  <inline-code>student</inline-code> are the names of the variables. Each holds a different type of information: a string, an integer, a decimal number, and a boolean value, respectively.

You can use variables in calculations or conditions in your program. For example:

<code-block>
age = age + 1  # This adds 1 to the value in the 'age' variable
print("Your age is:", age)
</code-block>

You can change the value of a variable at any time in your program, and the new value will replace the old one.

Remember, choose variable names that make sense and describe the values they hold to make your code easier to understand.
fields.article_content_ht:
Nan pwogramasyon Python, yon varyab se tankou yon bwat kote ou ka estoke enfòmasyon. Imajine li kòm yon etikèt ke ou kole sou yon valè pou ou ka reitilize li pita nan kòd ou san ou pa bezwen sonje egzakteman sa valè a te ye. Sa fè kòd la vin pi fasil pou li epi modifye.

Pou kreye yon varyab nan Python, ou senpleman bay li yon non epi asiyen yon valè avèk siy egal (`=`). Men kèk egzanp:

<code-block>
non = "Jean"
laj = 19
mwayèn = 85.5
elèv = True
</code-block>

Nan egzanp sa yo, <inline-code>`non`</inline-code>, <inline-code>`laj`</inline-code>, <inline-code>`mwayèn`</inline-code>, ak <inline-code>`elèv`</inline-code> se non varyab yo. Yo chak kenbe yon kalite enfòmasyon diferan: yon chèn karaktè, yon nimewo antye, yon nimewo desimal, ak yon valè boolyen, respektivman.

Ou ka itilize varyab yo nan kalkil oswa kondisyon nan pwogram ou. Pa egzanp:

<code-block>
laj = laj + 1  # Sa ajoute 1 nan valè ki nan varyab 'laj'
print("Laj ou se:", laj)
</code-block>

Ou kapab chanje valè yon varyab nenpòt ki lè nan pwogram ou, epi nouvo valè a pral ranplase ansyen valè a.

Sonje byen, chwazi non varyab ki gen sans e ki dekri valè yo kenbe pou fè kòd ou pi fasil pou konprann.

fields.article_content_en:
In Python, functions are organized and reusable blocks of code designed to perform a specific task. One way to think of functions is as recipes: you have the instructions (the code) and the ingredients (the information, such as variables), and when you follow the recipe, it produces something (the result).

To create a function in Python, you use the keyword <inline-code>def</inline-code>, followed by the name of the function and parentheses. Inside the parentheses, you can place parameters, which are like variables that will receive values when the function is called. Then, you add a block of code that defines what the function will do. Here's an example:

<code-block>
def greet(name):
    message = "Hello, " + name
    return message
</code-block>

In this example, <inline-code>greet</inline-code> is the name of the function, and <inline-code>name</inline-code> is the parameter. The function takes a name, combines it with the string "Hello, ", and returns the result.

To use the function, you call it by name and provide the required values:

<code-block>
result = greet("Jean")
print(result)  # Prints "Hello, Jean"
</code-block>

Functions can make the code clearer and easier to manage because they allow you to isolate parts of the code that do the same job, making it easier to read, debug, and reuse code.
fields.article_content_ht:
Nan Python, fonksyon yo se blòk kòd ki òganize epi ki ka reitilize, ki fèt pou fè yon travay espesifik. Yon fason pou imajine fonksyon se tankou yon resèt: ou genyen enstriksyon yo (kòd la) ak engredyan yo (enfòmasyon yo, tankou varyab), epi lè ou swiv resèt la, li pwodui yon bagay (rezilta a).

Pou kreye yon fonksyon nan Python, ou itilize mo kle <inline-code>def</inline-code>, swivi pa non fonksyon an ak parantèz. Anndan parantèz yo, ou ka mete paramèt, ki se tankou varyab yo ki pral resevwa valè lè fonksyon an apèl. Answit, ou ajoute yon blòk kòd ki defini sa fonksyon an pral fè. Men yon egzanp:

<code-block>
def salye(nom):
    mesaj = "Bonjou, " + nom
    return mesaj
</code-block>

Nan egzanp sa, <inline-code>salye</inline-code> se non fonksyon an, e <inline-code>nom</inline-code> se paramèt la. Fonksyon an pran yon non, konbine li ak chèn "Bonjou, ", epi retounen rezilta a.

Pou itilize fonksyon an, ou rele li pa non epi bay valè yo mande yo:

<code-block>
rezilta = salye("Jean")
print(rezilta)  # Afiche "Bonjou, Jean"
</code-block>

Fonksyon yo ka fè kòd la pi klè e pi fasil pou jere paske yo pèmèt ou izole pati nan kòd ki fè menm travay la, sa ki fè li pi fasil pou li, deboge, ak reitilize kòd.
